image.altText: An older man with greying light hair and glasses wearing a suit and tie stands in front of a blue Reserve Bank of Australia wall

items.synopsis: The RBA delivers a brief reprieve to mortgage borrowers by deciding to leave rates on hold at its July meeting, after two dozen protesters gather outside its headquarters in Sydney. Follow live.

title.children: RBA pauses interest rate rises 'to assess the state of the economy'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Looking solely at the data, it seems that rising interest rates are having an impact on inflation (which is measured as the consumer price index, or CPI for short). Of course, lifting rates comes with consequences, with mortgage borrowers and small business owners just some of those feeling the pinch. But looking at this graph in isolation, it certainly appears that rising interest rates are working to curb inflation in the economy. That said, the RBA takes in far more indicators into account than just the relationship of inflation and interest rates. (One other thing to note in this graph — the latest monthly inflation data is for May this year, so the cash rate figure is capped at the May rate of 3.85% for purposes of showing the trend.)
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Lifting interest rates is meant to bring down inflation. Is it working?

children.content: Looking solely at the data, it seems that rising interest rates are having an impact on inflation (which is measured as the consumer price index, or CPI for short).
Of course, lifting rates comes with consequences, with mortgage borrowers and small business owners just some of those feeling the pinch.
But looking at this graph in isolation, it certainly appears that rising interest rates are working to curb inflation in the economy.
That said, the RBA takes in far more indicators into account than just the relationship of inflation and interest rates.
(One other thing to note in this graph — the latest monthly inflation data is for May this year, so the cash rate figure is capped at the May rate of 3.85% for purposes of showing the trend.)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's been a mainstay feature of the RBA's statement after its meeting each month — but the central bank says "some further tightening of monetary policy may be required". That translates to more interest rate rises being likely in the coming months, with many analysts expecting there are at least two more rate rises to come before the RBA is finished with its current rate hiking cycle. Here's more of that statement from RBA governor Philip Lowe : "Some further tightening of monetary policy may be required to ensure that inflation returns to target in a reasonable timeframe, but that will depend upon how the economy and inflation evolve. "The decision to hold interest rates steady this month provides the Board with more time to assess the state of the economy and the economic outlook and associated risks. "In making its decisions, the Board will continue to pay close attention to developments in the global economy, trends in household spending, and the forecasts for inflation and the labour market. "The Board remains resolute in its determination to return inflation to target and will do what is necessary to achieve that."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: RBA warns further rate rises ahead

children.content: It's been a mainstay feature of the RBA's statement after its meeting each month — but the central bank says "some further tightening of monetary policy may be required".
That translates to
more interest rate rises being likely in the coming months
, with many analysts expecting there are at least two more rate rises to come before the RBA is finished with its current rate hiking cycle.
Here's more of that statement from
RBA governor Philip Lowe
"Some further tightening of monetary policy may be required to ensure that inflation returns to target in a reasonable timeframe, but that will depend upon how the economy and inflation evolve.
"The decision to hold interest rates steady this month provides the Board with more time to assess the state of the economy and the economic outlook and associated risks.
"In making its decisions, the Board will continue to pay close attention to developments in the global economy, trends in household spending, and the forecasts for inflation and the labour market.
"The Board remains resolute in its determination to return inflation to target and will do what is necessary to achieve that."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It might be a reprieve for borrowers this month, but the RBA says it's taking the coming month to assess the impact of current rate rises on the economy. Here's some of the RBA governor Philip Lowe's thinking in his statement: "Interest rates have been increased by 4 percentage points since May last year. "The higher interest rates are working to establish a more sustainable balance between supply and demand in the economy and will continue to do so. "In light of this and the uncertainty surrounding the economic outlook, the Board decided to hold interest rates steady this month. "This will provide some time to assess the impact of the increase in interest rates to date and the economic outlook."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Economic outlook 'uncertainty' behind RBA's decision to pause, Lowe says

children.content: It might be a reprieve for borrowers this month, but the RBA says it's taking the coming month to assess the impact of current rate rises on the economy.
Here's some of the
RBA governor Philip Lowe's
thinking in his statement:
"Interest rates have been increased by 4
percentage points since May last year.
"The higher interest rates are working to establish a more sustainable balance between supply and demand in the economy and will continue to do so.
"In light of this and the
uncertainty surrounding the economic outlook
, the Board decided to hold interest rates steady this month.
"This will provide some time to assess the impact of the increase in interest rates to date and the economic outlook."

title.children: Reserve Bank keeps rates on hold for July, but more hikes could be coming

title.children: Elkie wants her career to progress. But a childcare shortage has put that on hold

image.altText: An elderly woman with glasses smiling with a flower border. An elderly man with glasses smiling.

items.synopsis: A woman related to a 94-year-old woman and her husband, who died in hospital a year apart, has now been charged with two counts of murder after she was arrested earlier today, SA police say.

title.children: Female relative charged with murders of couple, both 94, who died a year apart

image.altText: Heather Anderson portrait

items.synopsis: Adelaide premiership player Heather Anderson, who took her own life last November aged 28, is the first known professional female athlete to be diagnosed with the degenerative brain disease chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE).

title.children: First professional female athlete diagnosed with CTE in landmark case months after her death in Perth

image.altText: Katherine Goodall lays in a hospital bed while giving a thumbs up

items.synopsis: A young mum has qualified as a surgeon despite a shock bowel cancer diagnosis part way through her training.

title.children: Young surgeon's shock bowel discovery highlights growing under 50s cancer risk

image.altText: A man reading a newspaper

items.synopsis: The rise of social media, soaring power bills and a break in the machine has led the owner and operator of the Don Dorrigo Gazette in New South Wales to close the 110-year-old paper.

title.children: Australia's last letterpress newspaper prints its final edition as costs, social media take a toll

image.altText: A man wearing a black jacket, plaid shirt and black beanie holds an acoustic guitar.

items.synopsis: What started off as a casually recorded folk song became a foundational entry in the Australian songbook.

title.children: It began with some chords strummed around a camp fire before becoming an Australian music legacy

image.altText: A composite image of two men of Chinese appearance.

items.synopsis: Two men living in Australia have criticised a move by Hong Kong authorities to issue them with arrest warrants under a controversial national security law, putting a $HK1 million bounty on their heads.

title.children: Adelaide man says warrant for his arrest in Hong Kong shows China is 'more a threat than a friend to the world'

items.synopsis: While many fret about the "slowness" of the Ukrainian campaign, all military operations consist of pulses and pauses and there is much we do not see in this war. It is important to remain patient, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: Ukraine's war campaign may seem 'slow', but its strategy is full of surprises — and Russia could be in trouble

title.children: Clouds blocked the buck supermoon for many in Australia, so here are photos of it from around the world

image.altText: A composite photo of Dr Karishma Dahia on the left and Laura Vissaritis on the right

items.synopsis: Join dog behaviourist Laura Vissaritis and vet Dr Karishma Dahia as they tackle some of your curly canine questions in our live Q&A.

title.children: Is your dog postie-obsessed or an excessive barker? Join our experts as they troubleshoot your canine challenges

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Lawrence : Our dogs are old and arthritic (12yo), hence we only walk them around the block, but one stops halfway and we almost have to drag her home. They need to walk to keep fitness and joint movement, but we don't want to force them. What should we do? Dr Karishma 's advice: Osteoarthritis is such a common ailment affecting many of our senior pets. Whilst it is true that we should still provide gentle exercise and enrichment to our geriatric pets, it is important not to over-do it or push them beyond their limits as this can hinder them more than help them. If you find that your dog's can only walk halfway around the block, then reduce their walks to this distance. This is their way of telling you that they are not physically capable of walking further than this without being in discomfort or pain. And as they continue to age, you will likely find that the length of these walks will reduce even further. A good alternative to walking outside if they are having trouble is spending more time in the garden with them so they still get the interaction and fresh air without pushing themselves. Another good alternative is swimming or hydrotherapy for our senior pets who enjoy the water, to keep their joints moving - although this is not for everyone! And finally getting them checked out at the vet is a great idea to get them on an osteoarthritis management plan and provide pain relief where needed. And if they are not at the stage of needing pain management, there are some fantastic natural injections and oral supplements these days that can greatly improve their quality of life and get them moving more freely again.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How do you help keep old dogs fit and healthy?

children.content: Lawrence

: Our dogs are old and arthritic (12yo), hence we only walk them around the block, but one stops halfway and we almost have to drag her home. They need to walk to keep fitness and joint movement, but we don't want to force them. What should we do?
Dr Karishma
's advice:

Osteoarthritis is such a common ailment affecting many of our senior pets. Whilst it is true that we should still provide gentle exercise and enrichment to our geriatric pets, it is important not to over-do it or push them beyond their limits as this can hinder them more than help
them. If you find that your dog's can only walk halfway around the block, then
reduce their walks

to this distance. This is their way of telling you that they are not physically capable of walking further than this without being in discomfort or pain. And as they continue to age, you will likely find that the length of these walks will reduce even further. A good alternative
to walking outside if they are having trouble is
spending more time in the garden
with them so they still get the interaction and fresh air without pushing themselves.
Another good alternative is
swimming or hydrotherapy
for our senior pets who enjoy the water, to keep their joints moving - although this is not for everyone!
And finally getting them checked out at the vet is a great idea to get them on an osteoarthritis management plan and provide pain relief where needed. And if they are not at the
stage of needing pain management, there are some fantastic natural injections and oral supplements these days that can greatly improve their quality of life and get them moving more freely again.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Stephen: How do we break a habit, a habit that does come and go,      of weeing in the house? Heidi: Why would my rescue dog suddenly wee on my bed right where I sleep? She is well trained, has no notable history of abuse and has been a delight to welcome into our home. Thanks Stephen and Heidi for you questions! I've put this to both Dr Karishma and Laura V. Dr Karishma: Breaking habits, especially ones that are intermittent can be a challenging and lengthy process. The first step is trying to identify the trigger for this behaviour. Some common reasons include territorial spraying if they are not desexed, from urinary incontinence, old age, osteoarthritis, dementia, stress/fear/anxiety - even to noise outside, kidney disease, diabetes, cushing's disease, or urinary tract infections/stones in the bladder. It's important to get your pet checked at the vet to identify any of these underlying issues. Once a trigger has been identified, it usually will make things easier to treat, especially if there is an underlying medical issue. If these things have been ruled out, then re-training your dog may include things like increasing toilet breaks - especially after sleep and rewarding them for peeing in appropriate places. As well as ensuring area's where they have previously urinated are thoroughly cleaned with an enzymatic cleaner that eliminates the smell so they can't recognoise that smell.And considering pheromone collars and diffuser's in the house to help they feel comfortable in their environment if they are an anxious dog. And here's Laura V's take: Laura V: Dogs will wee inside the house for a number of reasons - they have not been trained properly to go outdoors, or they have an underlying anxiety, or they have an underlying medical problem. If it is occasional, try to identify the pattern. If you can predict it, then you can prevent it, by calling your dog outside to the toilet. Putting your dog on a lead can also help as you can manage their behaviour more consistently, preventing them from sneaking away to wee in another room. There is always the possibility that your dog has an underlying infection or disease that needs to be addressed by your vet, so a check up is well worth it. Punishing dogs for having accidents inside only makes them more anxious and can make them more likely to sneak away in another room when you're not looking.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How do we break the habit of weeing in the house?

Once a trigger has been identified, it usually will make things easier to treat, especially if there is an underlying medical issue. If these things have

cleaner that eliminates the smell so they can't recognoise that smell.And considering pheromone collars and diffuser's
in the house to help they feel comfortable in their environment if they are an anxious dog.
And here's
Laura V's
take:
Laura V:
Dogs will wee inside
the house for a number of reasons - they have not been trained properly
to go outdoors, or they have an underlying anxiety, or they have an underlying medical problem. If it is occasional, try to
identify
the pattern

. If you can predict it, then you can prevent it, by calling your dog outside to the toilet. Putting your dog on a lead can also help as you can manage their behaviour more consistently, preventing them from sneaking away to wee in another room.
There is always the possibility that your dog has an
underlying infection or disease

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Stephen: My dog looks like he is chewing on something but his mouth is empty. He usually does this for 15 to 30 minutes in the evening then stops when he goes to bed. I’ve had his mouth checked at the vet. What is causing this? Thanks for reaching out with that one Stephen. I've put it to Dr Karishma who says : Dr Karishma: Sometimes dog's can teeth grind just like in people! I usually will do a full oral examination to check for any dental disease, tooth root abscesses, foreign bodies, masses/cancers or swellings in the mouth that can contribute to abnormal chewing. As well as checking the jaw for any pain, malocculusions, abnormal jaw alignment or resistance when opening/closing the jaw. I will usually follow this up with imaging of the jaw and teeth to ensure there are no lesions to the jaw or teeth that can not be seen from visual inspection alone - especially below the gum line. If this is all clear, and he is not showing any signs of pain, likely it's a behavioural displacement behaviour secondary to stress, fear or anxiety. Or even a learnt comfort behaviour, especially if it dissipates in the evenings when he is likely feeling very comfortable and getting into bed. Some dog's will actually suck on a blanket or hold items in their mouth too as a form of comfort.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Why is my dog excessively chewing?

image.altText: A black-and-white image of a circus performer with a modern-day image of a man in Toreador costume.

title.children: Easing of visa rules for Indonesians flagged as president arrives in Sydney

image.altText: A bearded man in front of a river wearing a wide brim hat slightly smiling at the camera

items.synopsis: Ray Burgess was diagnosed with advanced cancer but didn't receive treatment for months due to long outpatient waitlists and lack of specialised equipment.

title.children: Ray's GP told him he had colon cancer in December. He couldn't begin treatment until May, and by June he was dead

image.altText: A collection of maneki-neko or lucky cat statues.

items.synopsis: Maneki-neko — otherwise known as lucky cats or welcoming cats — are found around the world. But where the ceramic cats began to be sold remains a mystery, writes Tets Kimura.

title.children: They're now found behind cash registers all over the world, but where did the beckoning cat come from?
